headline: Customer Service is Horrible and Lies
reviewBody:
3/27-signed up for Coursera and applied for financial aid
4/10-FA app approved. Prompted to verify my ID 
4/11-attempted 64 times with different phones, tablets, PC to verify ID in daylight, inside light, LED light, etc FAILED-contacted support (ticket 2737097)-nothing they can do I must keep trying.
5/19-trying again to verify my ID. Tried dozens of times, even when on live Chat Help (ticket 2795238). FAILED. 
5/19-Carrie, from Coursera, advised me to send a picture of the errors I encountered, and I sent them. Carrie then advised me "I was investigating on my end and it appears the issue you are experiencing is already a known problem on our end. Currently, I have reported the issue you are experiencing with the ID verification to our engineering team and they will be working as fast as possible to have this matter resolved." then she assured me "In this case, we have escalated the issue to our support team. They will be helping us to manually approve your ID verification. Please, give us a few more days to complete this verification for you."
6/8, today-account still not verified and I am still unable to. 

Is the problem Persona? Is the problem Coursera? I have no idea but I know the customer service fails are Coursera (I have yet to find a CS number for Persona). I waited to write this review to ensure that Coursera had enough time to act in good faith IF THEY HAD ANY intentions of doing so. FAILED.

headline: Charging me for individual courses even tho I've the 1-year subscription!
reviewBody:
I was enrolled on two courses. Then, on a whim, decided to take up on the one-year subscription which was 340 euros. Fast forward about three months, I can't believe my eyes when I see that they've still been charging me for those courses even though they most definitely belong to the 'Plus'-category (meaning they are included in the yearly subscription). So they've sucked my blood to the tune of 280 euros! I'm trying to find someone to talk to now. Reading these reviews, I'm not holding my breath.

*UPDATE*: The effect of reading these reviews was that I was actually surprised when I was contacted by Coursera support! Anyways, they agreed to refund the individual monthly charges that should've been already covered by the yearly subscription and were very amiable while at it, so I'm upgrading my review a bit.

headline: Buying worthless PDFs
reviewBody: I enrolled on a course and it was completely bogus, you had as many attempts as you like on the quiz and after one go you get given all the right answers.  the final grade was achieved by writing one sentence about how you feel.  had many emails go back and forth today with customer support #2664902 and they won't award me the certificate despite doing 7 weeks worth of bogus tests and listening to someone's inflated opinions and tokenism.  enrolled on another course about writing a novel and in the student group, most of the students can't write a basic sentence without spelling almost every word wrong.  there are a few good courses on here but they are few and far between.  if you want to buy worthless certificates in a PDF format it's the place to go!!

headline: Course grading is a scam
reviewBody: The course was excellent.  Coursera, on the other hand, was a nightmare.  Getting customer service is almost impossible -- they have no way to speak to a human.  They delayed my grade so they could charge me for another month. When I complained they said that they would give me the lowest possible grade if I didn't want to wait to be graded.  They then did that without contacting me. I did 5 peer reviews.  Only 1 person (probably admin and not a student) gave "content is satisfactory" feedback without ever reviewing my content.  I know that because my assignment was on a fileshare that alerts me when it's accessed. NOBODY ACCESSED IT.  So the grade was a scam.  I spend several days on this assignment only to find out that NOBODY reviews your work, and somebody puts in a fake low grade to shut you up if you complain.  I was interested in taking other courses, but because of the scam involved in grading, never doing this again.

The 2 stars are for Coursera alone. I spent a number of hours at the end to do my assignment. It was clear that the other students were not putting in any where near as much effort. It was common to see comments on the discussion page saying things like I’ll give you all 5s if you give me all 5s. 
Most of the answers I read were (being kind now) not great. I gave detailed constructive criticism. What did I get in return; 5/5 for everything and comments: good. 
Honestly I would not hire anybody based on this course and so I feel I have wasted my time. (Though saying all that the course itself was a pleasure and gave me something to aspire to🤔)
The scary part is that these people are hopeful managers! (Or worse still, already managers) 🤦‍♂️

headline: The good, the bad and the ugly
reviewBody: I undertook the 4 part  'Memoir and Personal Essay: Write About Yourself Specialization'. The course exercises were excellent although sometimes poorly explained. The quality of the transcripts is abysmal; every transcript is scattered with errors, including many which alter the fundamental meaning of the sentence. (Don't they proofread??!!) Two sessions relied on a pdf that was missing so those 2 sessions were worthless. Despite the poor quality, I was motivated to write and I learned something so all is not lost. However, for a paid course, I expect better. It should also be made clear that the only reviews a learner will receive are peer reviews - there is absolutely no tutor/learner interaction. There is also a major issue with having to complete 3 peer reviews when the learner is told repeatedly that there are no reviews available! Very frustrating. Finally, although I enjoyed this course and learned something, Coursera needs to be aware that there are many other excellent sources of online learning and if they want to maintain their reputation (or improve it!) they need to up their game and improve the content quality and accuracy. I did complain about the transcript errors and was told someone would reply to me in 24 hours. That was a month ago so I'm not optimistic that anyone even read the complaint let alone dealt with it.

headline: The problem is that .... the billing method deserves disrespect.

This is like a cashback industry that happened with mobile phones sometime back, they say at a future date if you send in the bills, you will get cashback, but most of us will not do it at a future date and the companies make money.  Similarly coursera makes money from people who forget to cancel the subscription on time.  May not be illegal, but deserves some disrespect for how they make money. headline: Shoddy scam merchants
reviewBody:
A poorly executed, shoddy, ripoff company. The courses are highly variable in terms of quality, and the only skill you are guaranteed to improve is your cutting and pasting. However the customer support is where these scam merchants make their money. To sign up, you are forced in most cases to take a "free 7-day trial", it's not optional, and under their T&Cs, to continue the course, you must pay a £40 a month subscription. The trap ? Any subscription that starts with a free trial is subsequently non-refundable, so unless you finish the course in 7 days and cancel, your money's gone. This might not be a big deal, but multiply it by thousands of locked-in students and you can see where they make their money.

The problem arose for me after taking eleven out of twelve courses towards an IBM Professional Certificate. When I came to take the final one, I was informed that I had to choose a session to enroll on, but that there were no future sessions planned. I was told I couldn't have a refund as apparently my subscription had started with a free trial, and that future sessions, if any would ever take place, were outside Cousera's control, so I could keep paying and wait, or go f*** myself. I'm currently writing it up as a case study in bad business practice for use in my university lectures, and am seeking legal advice with a view to forming a class action. Not only will I never use Coursera again, I will be proactively warning hundreds of students each year to find alternatives too.

headline: Interesting Content, Terrible Implementation
reviewBody:
I started the Transmedia Writing course. The content was fine, but the peer review assessment process was terrible. After spending a lot of time reviewing and providing written feedback to other learners, I did not get any written feedback. On my third assignment, there were technical issues and I couldn’t move forward in the course because I was unable to review anyone else’s work. So, my first two assignment marks were based on one peer review which was nothing more than another learning answering yes or no to a five question rubric. 

As well, there are no prerequisites for courses, so you never know what kind of peer feedback you will get, if you get any at all. With no feedback, it is very difficult to improve your work. I know a lot of work goes into creating courses, but without considered course delivery and implementation the course is little more than chunked information. And when it is a creative course, meaningful feedback is essential. 

I asked for a refund and was told that they don’t give refunds past two weeks. I was persistent and I did get a refund but they were not pleased to do so. They also refunded me less than what I paid, as they sent in Canadian funds what I had paid in US dollars. Sneaky. Money. Grab.

It's somewhat annoying that I can only see my notes on a video by clicking on the video itself. This makes reviewing my notes difficult. I'd like to be able to see all my notes for a course on one page.

headline: Great quality courses
reviewBody:
I've been using Coursera for over 5 years already and have completed a few specializations. I didn't find any issues with pricing and grading system for as long as you know how to read and pay attention. The style of teaching is academically inclined to ensure you learn the concepts before application. You will have the opportunity to apply what you have learn through graded peer-to-peer assignments or capstone projects. As with anything else, you have to make sure that you try to diligently finish the course because it's not all the time that there will be enough students who will take up the course the same time as you do, especially that you can always reset your deadlines. To make sure that your work will graded in time, try to do your part as well to reach out to discussion/forums to ask for anyone to grade your work.

If you are actively using Coursera, you'll learn to appreciate how great the platform and courses are.

Disclaimer: I am not affiliated with Coursera. I am just a loyal user.

headline: A service has to be exceptionally bad…
reviewBody: A service has to be exceptionally bad or shady for me to trash it in a review, but do yourselves a favour and stay away from Coursera. I signed up for a paid specialisation that I did not like. I am pretty sure I cancelled the service sometime in early August (having recently paid a new month starting July 26) and forgot about this outdated platform, until now that I just got a charge in my account for their monthly fee. The second the payment came in, I rushed to see my subscription, only to realise it had never been cancelled despite me being sure I did it (guessing the cancellation didn't go through). Because I began the specialisation on a free trial, their policy states a refund is not possible, even though I have not used their services in the last month and cancelled the subscription (again) not 5 minutes after I was alerted of the new payment. Still trying to get my refund but my whole experience with coursera was a nightmare, from the format of their webpage (inconvenient to look at the lecture video and the transcript at the same time), to the quality of their lectures (extremely unengaging, constant stuttering and monotone), to the pace of their courses (they teach to crawl and then their exercises throw you in a pool and ask you swim). I'd accept it's a me issue if I were alone in this sentiment, but considering my partner learned all his coding skills online to switch careers and now has a job as a software engineer and even he dislikes this course the company asked him to take via this platform, I'm going to assume coursera has just stayed behind compared to other online resources. Thanks coursera for robbing me of a week's worth of groceries. I hope once this refund thing is settled I never have to deal with you again.

headline: Great MOOC platform turned into garbage
reviewBody:

But their platform didn't get any better, in fact the site gets only worse. They had working components, but now:

- Course search is very poor, lots of noise. When I search algorithm courses I see... Deep Learning, which also belongs in Machine Learning. Overlapping categories, seriously?

- Filtering by language works sporadically (sometimes it hangs, sometimes it just doesn't filter)

- Sometimes they even put courses that can't be finished (because of broken assignments) and don't mention technical difficulties - for example Reinforcement Learning course from Advanced ML was impossible to finish for some time, and the only way to find that out was to read reviews and course forum.

It seems like they prefer quantity over quality - there are more courses than ever, they seem to add less-than-great ones, and combined with crappy platform, it only makes finding valuable stuff harder.

headline: Cheaters ruining the grading system and Coursera does nothing about it
reviewBody:

In the past, I had to reject multiple works as they were just simply copied from the internet; even the names and dates were wrong in them, clearly showing that the source was Github and similar sites, not the students who were suppused to create them.

Even worse, when I do not give maximum points to assignments that do not work at all, then in revenge they give less points to me for work that give the correct results and this can be proven easily. I cannot even talk to the teacher to report this behaviour.

Finally, I am not happy about not being able to get a certificate for a course just because I waited too long to ask for it. They can easily see I have taken it, so why then?

[09/07/2019]
I am trying to cancel my subscription but it just keeps asking me if  I am sure I want to do it. I have clicked "Yes" about 10 times by now, but it just keeps doing this. I honestly cannot believe how low Coursera has managed to descend!

headline: Non existing consumer safety, but some good courses.
reviewBody: This review is based on Coursera as a course provider relating to consumer safety, and not the academic quality of the courses. I like some of the courses on Coursera, however it depends on the university/organization responsible for the course. You should know that some course providers offer their own solutions where you take tests and exams. If one of those solutions is out of order, you won’t be compensated either with money or an extension to your Subscription. During a course provided by IBM, their cloud service broke down for a couple of days. I contacted Coursera to get an extension to my subscription according to the days the service was down, but that was not possible according to support. In conclusion you can find some good courses, but Coursera as an organization offers no consumer safety, and if a problem arises you will lose your money.

I liked the fact that I had to do some homework each week, and that it was graded by peers, even though that system isn't perfect - some peers gave some insightful, constructive feedback on my work, others clearly just didn't put much time or energy into it and gave some generic feedback that wasn't especially helpful. 
I also liked the fact that many sessions are available and you can just switch sessions when you're getting behind on the session you are in - really good flexibility.
The UI is intuitive and clear, pleasant to use.
I would recommend this platform and wouldn't hesitate to enroll in more courses on it in future.

headline: Peer grading is just such a bad idea…
reviewBody:
Peer grading is just such a bad idea from a learners perspective. The reason you go to school to become a teacher is so you know how to review and grade your students work in a fair and professional manner.

When you leave this task up to the learners it becomes a real mess. As peoples reviewing skills vary widely. It's like asking someone to drive a car without a license. You just cannot predict the outcome. Because you have no idea what their past experience is. That's just crazy. And I would not trust them behind the wheel.

There is a real fear in the course that work will not even be graded at all. Peer grading is just a way for the course to be a self sufficient money spinner. It's no way to educate people.

And it's not good value for money. (e.g. I paid almost $1,000 for my course) And I may fail because a stranger decided they don't like me or my work. Or they just could not be bothered scoring my work. Even though I would easily pass from a real teachers point of view.  On the plus side people can pass easily with minimum effort.  If their peer reviewer is too kind. It's the luck of the draw. Here in the wild west.

It's an extremely lazy and money grubbing way to do things. Sorry to tell you. But you fail Cousera. For not turning up to class. I am not a professional reviewer or educator. So this review may be unfair. Just like the ones in your courses.

PS. Thanks Trustpilot for spreading the word.

PPS. Finished the course. While peer reviewing the final assignment. I noticed 2 students cheating. They simply linked to another student's website and said it was their own. I flagged these people to Coursera. But if I spotted it so easily. How much of this behaviour is really going on across the whole system? It's pretty disturbing to think about.

headline: Read this for refunds.
reviewBody:
There are other places you can learn online that are more reputable and have fairer policies that aren't overt money grabs. 

I decided to try a 7 day free trial when I found a course I wanted to take a look at.  Good thing I did - it wasn't for me.  I thought I had cancelled the auto renewal so you can imagine my confusion when a few days later I received an email receipt for my subscription charge.

I contacted their customer chat bot, was connected to a CSR, and asked for a refund. I was immediately given their "policy" - that after a free trial no refunds are given.  This policy is to get you to accept the money has left your account and into their coffers.    

It took me quoting, as a UK resident, the UK Statutory rights, for them to make a "one off exception" to the rule and provide me with a full refund. If you are in the UK, please make sure to quote your statutory rights and do not accept their "policy" as it's not compliant with consumer protection. 

Oh, and as they're distance selling, if you've been charged and it's past your 14 day statutory rights, Coursera doesn't advise you of your rights on the website and therefore your right to request a refund is automatically extended to 12 months.  

Additionally, it’s "illegal to display any notice that deliberately misleads consumers or deceives them about their rights, eg a sign that says you don’t accept returns or offer refunds".

headline: Appalling customer "support"
reviewBody:
Contacted their customer support about charges to my credit card (finding how to contact their customer support in their "Help" Center is itself an ordeal worth a separate review). Received no substantive feedback - only insolent boilerplate answers. I have completed about ten paid (i.e. certificate) courses with them thus far, but I will never again enroll there. 

Some courses were really cool (Andrew Ng's was one of my favourites - truly enjoyable and useful). Other courses are, however, quite unsatisfactory (examples: UToronto's iOS; UCSD's Introduction to Big Data (2015)). However, I generally like that the course providers are academic institutions, and some of the courses are at reasonably high level.

Edit: after a couple of further rounds with their support they did resolve my issue.

headline: Biggest issue I have is that the work …
reviewBody:
Biggest issue I have is that the work we did was reviewed and rated by classmates. The feedback is always helpful, of course, but I expected the instructor to give at least a portion of the final grade. Instead, we were told to review at least four other projects, have our work reviewed by at least four other classmates, and not a peep from the instructor. Worse, we were told that we'd be informed via email as soon as other projects are available for review which never happened. 

Whenever I posted on the forum, a mentor would reply a few days after with a vague response about how having peer reviews are helpful but nothing about how that makes the certification even credible.

Worse, you have to keep requesting for people to review your work. I saw other people begging for reviews because they needed the certification asap. I don't think that's how it's supposed to work.

My suggestion is take the free option. The instructor I had was good and I did learn a few things. Unfortunately, I'm not sure I'll get the certification because the session I joined had ended before anyone could review some of the projects I submitted.

The courses offered are through accredited universities from all over the world. It is so incredible that anyone can take these classes for free. If you haven't already checked it out and taken a class, I highly recommend that you sign up for one today!

headline: The Future of Education is here
reviewBody:
Over the past half year I have followed five courses on Coursera, and they have all been of excellent quality. Pretty much all courses are made and run by recognized professors from well-known universities around the world.

In fact, I would gladly pay a small amount to take these courses, but they are completely free for anyone, which is quite amazing.

There are literally hundreds of different courses to choose from, ranging from computer science to engineering to social sciences. It would be truly strange if you could not find a course that you find interesting here.

I would say that one Coursera course corresponds roughly to half of one high-level university course. There is some homework involved if you want to get a cerficate of completion, but fortunately Coursera students help each other a lot in the forums (there is an online forum for each course).

You can also just choose to watch the lectures, and not do the homework, if your time is limited.

Coursera cannot be recommended highly enough for those of us who want to keep improving their knowledge of the world and/or get new skills for our jobs. This style of learning suits me better than a real-life university, since with Coursera you can easily review lectures on video as many times as you need.

Just be sure to start easy and don't take too many courses at once (as I did), or you may find yourself a bit overwhelmed by the workload.

I will continue to take many courses on Coursera, that is for sure.
